reviewText: I want a chance to purchase the first season of Harry's Law on DVD. No excuses, no more delays or armpit scratching or nasal snorting. Make the first year of this highly original series available to us discerning types as an act of creative faith. Just about any piece of junk winds up on DVD these days ... but not Harry's Law? The first season was and is a singular demonstration of creator David Kelley's narrative genius (though not the formulaic and sadly compromised second season, unfortunately).  Harry's Law in Season One was fiction writing at its best. Allow us to wallow in it via repeated viewings. No more stalling! Thank you.- Al Hooper  (E-HOOPER.COM)

reviewText: This legal "dramedy" stars the extremely talented Kathy Bates (Academy Award for Best Actress forMisery) as Harriet "Harry" Korn, a 60-year-old, high-roller patent attorney from Cincinnati who has become so burned out, she does nothing at her job but smoke marijuana, eat junk food and watch cartoons until her boss fires her. Shortly thereafter, she starts an unconventional law practice by taking over a former shoe store and pursuing criminal defense in a dangerous inner-city neighborhood. In the process, she forms an eccentric family of affiliation with three other people who join her project. Brittany Snow (Finding Amanda, John Tucker Must Die) plays Jenna Backstrom, Harry's beautiful, twenty-something assistant from her former job. Nathan/Nate Corddry (United States of Tara, Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip) is Adam Branch, a young, idealistic, corporate-law hotshot who, like Harry, wants a more meaningful legal practice. British actor Aml Ameen (The Bill) plays Malcolm Davies, a brilliant, 19-year-old whom Harry meets when, while trying to commit suicide, he jumps off a building and lands on top of her. Harry helps him out of poverty-based trouble with the law and then offers him a position in her firm as an intern. In addition, though not part of Harry's firm, Christopher McDonald (Family Law, Veronica's Closet) appears in every episode but the pilot as humorously bombastic, media-hog attorney, Tommy Jefferson, who begins as an antagonist to Harry and ends up as an unlikely ally on multiple cases.This NBC series is written and produced by David E. Kelley, who is known for other quirky legal dramas, includingAlly McBeal,The PracticeandBoston Legal. The first season includes 12 episodes:1. Pilot, January 17, 20112. Heat of Passion, January 24, 20113. Innocent Man, January 31, 20114. Wheels of Justice, February 7, 20115. A Day in the Life, February 14, 20116. Bangers in the House, February 21, 20117. American Dreams, February 28, 20118. In the Ghetto, March 7, 20119. The Fragile Beast, March 14, 201110. Send in the Clowns, March 21, 201111. With Friends Like These...., March 28, 201112. Last Dance, April 4, 2011Besides the Academy Award, Kathy Bates has won endless other honors, and she is equally adept at dramatic and comic acting--which is quite a feat, and one that comes in quite handy for a show such as this that requires both abilities. She is riveting in every scene in which she appears.Of the other regulars on the show, my favorite is Christopher McDonald. His scenes with Kathy Bates are quite funny as their approaches to practicing law clash. Harry prefers a low profile, but Tommy Jefferson is extremely competitive and never sees a TV camera he doesn't love.The show also has a number of excellent actors with recurring roles, in particular Jordana Spiro (My Boys) as Rachael Miller, Adam's former fiancée and a coworker at the firm he left, and Johnny Ray Gill as Damien Winslow. Damien is the proud CEO of Winslow Protection I.N.C. He first appears as an apparent gang banger looking for protection money, and Harriet offers to defend him pro bono in exchange for a waiver of his protection fee. He is one of the more colorful characters on the show, and Mr. Gill does an outstanding job with the part. Paul McCrane (Dr. Robert Romano on ER) plays Josh "Puck" Peyton, a District Attorney who is frequently defeated by Harriet and fiercely resents it. This character is as humorously flamboyant as Tommy in his own way.There are also guest appearances by actors who starred previously in Kelley's series, The Practice. Camryn Manheim plays Kim Mendelsohn, a District Attorney who is embarrassed by the fact that she used to date Tommy Jefferson. Steve Harris appears in Episode 3 as a man in prison who has been wrongly convicted of murder.At times in the beginning of the season, some of Kelley's scenes come off with a preachy tone that reminds me of Aaron Sorkin's writing forThe West Wing. I personally like this show and enjoyed TWW in spite of the preaching rather than because of it. For my taste, it drags down the action, especially when the preaching makes little sense. For example, during a court scene in Episode 2 Harry proclaims to the jury that her client, an 80-year-old woman, had no other choice than to rob a store at gunpoint because she was poor and hungry. However, that unfortunate claim is mitigated by the fact that Harry herself realizes it is ridiculous but she is forced to use it as a last ditch effort to appeal to the emotions of the jury to keep the old lady from spending her last few years in jail. In addition, I think David Kelley must have been listening to the complaints from people watching the show in the comments section of many entertainment blogs, because the preaching substantially lessens over the course of the season until by the end there is hardly any.By the way, the 80-year-old armed robber is played by another wonderful guest actor, the awe-inspiring Irma P. Hall. Ms. Hall is an extraordinary talent who has appeared in films and TV shows since the 1970s and is best known for her parts as a matriarch in A Family Thing,Soul Food, and The Ladykillers. I loved seeing her go toe to toe with Kathy Bates. The two of them on stage together are mind bogglingly good.I rate this show as follows:Acting 5 starsScripts - 4.5 starsComedy - 5 starsDrama - 4 stars
summary: A quirky, hour-long legal show starring world-class actress Kathy Bates

reviewText: We love this show!  We love Kathy Bates!I cannot believe that NBC is cancelling it because the demographic is "too old."  What is that all about?  Baby boomers have the most disposable income of any "demographic.' So the audience loses and the advertisers lose too. And yes, we've written to NBC to complain.This show is well written, well acted and not everybody in it is "pretty" or a size 2.  (Granted there ARE some ladies like that but they're still great.)  I didn't enjoy season 2 locale change as much (out of the shoe store) but I think this show is gutsy and fun and SMART!!  Both Seasons!
Title: N/A

reviewText: From David E. Kelley, the creative connoisseur of legal drama, comes NBC's "Harry's Law", the latest addictive sensation which carries with it some of the delightfully quirky undertones of "Boston Legal" - yet has a freshness all of its own, with a first-class ensemble cast, headed by Kathy Bates.  Like William Shatner's take on the character of "Denny Crane", I could not imagine anyone other than Kathy Bates playing "Harrie".  This is a very special little gem!!!!!
summary: NBC gives David E. Kelley the stamp of "Approval"....And so do I
